security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown and JSON files. It provides Go concurrency patterns and code examples with no executable scripts, no filesystem access beyond its own files, no network calls, and no environment variable access. The skill is completely safe.

content.value_statement: Concurrent Go code is hard to design and debug. This skill provides proven patterns, examples, and best practices you can adapt quickly.
actual_capabilities: Explains goroutines, channels, select, and sync primitives with examples
Provides a worker pool pattern with context cancellation
Shows fan-out and fan-in pipeline patterns for parallel processing
Demonstrates bounded concurrency with semaphore patterns
Includes graceful shutdown using context and OS signals
Covers errgroup usage with cancellation and concurrency limits
limitations: Does not execute or test code in your environment
Does not provide project specific architecture guidance
Examples are Go focused and not cross language compatible
Does not include benchmarking or profiling steps

use_cases.title: Design concurrent services
use_cases.description: Select worker, pipeline, and cancellation patterns for production services.

use_cases.title: Plan graceful shutdowns
use_cases.description: Add safe shutdown and timeout handling to long running processes.

use_cases.title: Understand concurrency basics
use_cases.description: Learn goroutines, channels, and synchronization with clear examples.

prompt_templates.title: Explain goroutines
prompt_templates.prompt: Explain goroutines and channels with a small example for a beginner.

prompt_templates.title: Build a worker pool
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a worker pool pattern in Go with context cancellation, job channel, and results channel.

prompt_templates.title: Add graceful shutdown
prompt_templates.prompt: Show a graceful shutdown pattern using context and OS signals, with a short explanation.

prompt_templates.title: Limit concurrency
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare semaphore and errgroup limit patterns and recommend one for API fetch tasks.

output_examples.input: Suggest a pattern for processing many jobs with cancellation.
output: Use a worker pool with a buffered jobs channel
Pass a context to stop workers on cancel
Close results channel after all workers finish
Add errgroup when you need early failure on error

best_practices: Use context for cancellation and deadlines in all concurrent operations
Close channels from the sender side only to avoid panics
Ensure goroutines have a clear exit path and check ctx.Done regularly
anti_patterns: Using time.Sleep for synchronization instead of proper primitives
Closing channels from the receiver side which causes panics
Ignoring ctx.Done in long running loops leading to goroutine leaks

faq.question: Is this compatible with all Go versions?
faq.answer: Examples target modern Go and mostly work from Go 1.17 and newer.

faq.question: What are the limits of this skill?
faq.answer: It provides patterns and examples, not project specific design or testing services.

faq.question: Can it integrate with my codebase?
faq.answer: Yes, you can adapt the code snippets to your services and libraries directly.

faq.question: Does it access my data or secrets?
faq.answer: No, it only provides documentation and code examples without any execution.

faq.question: What if a pattern causes deadlocks?
faq.answer: Review channel ownership rules, add context cancellation, and test with go test -race.

faq.question: How does it compare to generic Go help?
faq.answer: It focuses specifically on concurrency patterns with reusable templates and best practices.
